üõë This file is source code, not the primary documentation location! üõë

See https://typescript-eslint.io/rules/consistent-generic-constructors for documentation.

When constructing a generic class, you can specify the type arguments on either the left-hand side (as a type annotation) or the right-hand side (as part of the constructor call):

// Left-hand side
const map: Map<string, number> = new Map();

// Right-hand side
const map = new Map<string, number>();

This rule ensures that type arguments appear consistently on one side of the declaration. Keeping to one side consistently improve code readability.

The rule never reports when there are type parameters on both sides, or neither sides of the declaration. It also doesn‚Äôt report if the names of the type annotation and the constructor don‚Äôt match.

Options

  • constructor (default): type arguments that only appear on the type annotation are disallowed.
  • type-annotation: type arguments that only appear on the constructor are disallowed.

constructor

‚ùå Incorrect

const map: Map<string, number> = new Map();
const set: Set<string> = new Set();

‚úÖ Correct

const map = new Map<string, number>();
const map: Map<string, number> = new MyMap();
const set = new Set<string>();
const set = new Set();
const set: Set<string> = new Set<string>();

type-annotation

‚ùå Incorrect

const map = new Map<string, number>();
const set = new Set<string>();

‚úÖ Correct

const map: Map<string, number> = new Map();
const set: Set<string> = new Set();
const set = new Set();
const set: Set<string> = new Set<string>();

When Not To Use It

You can turn this rule off if you don‚Äôt want to enforce one kind of generic constructor style over the other.
